issues.title: (from Qin) Factorize scheduled ACLs
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
Happy new year, Qiufang and I are working on the update of draft-ma-opsawg-ucl-acl, we haven't finished yet, but like to share the draft version(see attached).
One issue we have addressed in the latest version is to factor out calendar data from UCL YANG model, defined them as grouping,
```
   module: ietf-calendar
     grouping period:
       +-- period-of-time
          +-- (forms)?
             +--:(period-explicit)
             |  +-- explicit-start?   yang:date-and-time
             |  +-- explicit-end?     yang:date-and-time
             +--:(period-start)
                +-- start?            yang:date-and-time
                +-- duration?         yang:time-no-zone
     grouping recurrence:
       +-- recurrence
          +-- freq           enumeration
          +-- (until-or-count)?
          |  +--:(until)
          |  |  +-- until?   union
          |  +--:(count)
          |     +-- count?   uint32
          +-- interval?      uint32
          +-- bysecond*      uint32
          +-- byminute*      uint32
          +-- byhour*        uint32
          +-- byday* [weekday]
          |  +-- direction?   int32
          |  +-- weekday?     ical:weekday
          +-- bymonthday*    int32
          +-- byyearday*     int32
          +-- byyearweek*    int32
          +-- byyearmonth*   uint32
          +-- bysetpos*      int32
          +-- wkst*          ical:weekday

```
So we can reuses these grouping in the following YANG snippet:
```
        augment "/acl:acls/acl:acl/acl:aces/acl:ace" {
          if-feature "match-on-time";
          description
            "Add a new parameter to the Access Control Entry (ACE).";
          container time-range {
            description
              "This container defines when the access control
               entry rules are in effect.
               If it is not configured, the access control entry
               is immediately and always in effect.";
            choice time-range-type {
              description
                "Choice based on the type of the time range.";
              case periodic-range {
                description
                  "A periodic range of time to take effect.";
                uses ical:recurrence;
              }
              case absolute-range {
                description
                  "A single precise period of time to take effect.";
                uses ical:period;
              }
            }
          }
        }
```
I am wondering these part should be factored into draft-dbb-netmod-acl-03?

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body: Wait until having an stable version of the draft

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: covered in the UCL OPSAWG draft

issues.title: EVPN Filtering
issues.author: sbarguil
issues.body:
Hi all,

For the EVPN use case it is intering to consider additional filters such as:

- Service identifiers (MAC ISID Filter Policy): 

Provider backbone bridging (PBB) was originally defined as IEEE 802.1ah standard, and operates in exactly the same manner as IEEE 802.1ad standard. However, instead of multiplexing VLANs, PBB duplicates the MAC layer of the customer frame and separates it from the provider domain, by encapsulating it in a 24 bit instance service identifier (I-SID). This allows for complete transparency between the customer network and the provider network.

The I-component forms the customer or access facing interface or routing instance. The I-component is responsible for mapping customer Ethernet traffic to the appropriate I-SID. In the netrowk is mandatory to configure the default service identifier (I-SID).

Beign able to filter by I-Component Service identifier is a feature of the PBB configuration. 

```
mac-filter 90 create
	description "filter-wan-man"
	scope template
	type isid
	entry 1 create
		description "drop-local-isids"
		match
			isid 100 to 1000
		exit
		action drop
	exit
	entry 2 create
		description "allow-wan-isids"
		match
			isid 150
		exit
		action forward
	exit
```

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body: @sbarguil Please provide a motivation of the use case for both functionalities.

comments.author: sbarguil
comments.body:
With more innovative technologies like VLAN Based-EVPN as decribed by [Juniper](https://www.juniper.net/documentation/us/en/software/junos/evpn-vxlan/topics/concept/evpn-based-services.html), VxLAN implemented by [Cisco](https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/td/docs/switches/lan/catalyst6500/ios/12-2SX/configuration/guide/book/vacl.html#14906) or as [Huawei](https://support.huawei.com/enterprise/en/doc/EDOC1000178116/671214b/how-can-i-apply-an-acl-to-a-vlan)  simply the flexibility to apply a traffic filter to a VLAN; there is a common necessity to control all packets that are bridged within a VLAN or that are routed into or out of a VLAN or a WAN interface for the ACL capture.. 

It can be defined as:

- traffic-filter vlan _vlan-id_ inbound acl _acl-name_
- traffic-filter vlan _vlan-id_ outbound acl _acl-name_

The _vlan-id_ can be a single vlan a range or a list. 

For example include vlans from 12 to 16:
- traffic-filter vlan *12-16* inbound acl _acl-name_

For example include vlan 2 and vlans from 4 to 6:
- traffic-filter vlan *2*, *4-6* outbound acl _acl-name_
 
- Vlan IDs (MAC VID Filter Policy)

```
      default-action forward
      type vic
      entry 1 create
         match frame-type ethernet_II
           ouiter-tag 85 4095
         exit
         action drop
      exit
      entry 2 create
         match frame-type ethernet_II
           ouiter-tag 43 4095
         exit
         action drop
      exit   
```

comments.author: sbarguil
comments.body: To cover the range in the VLAN filter; Each modification muist include the sample usage in the I-D Document

issues.title: Action Redirect
issues.author: sbarguil
issues.body:
Can we complement the actions with a redirect option.

This will be highly dependant of the routers capabilities but this redirection can be to a Captive Portal for HTTP traffic, for example:

```
            entry 30 create
                match protocol tcp
                    dst-ip 10.10.10.91/24
                    dst-port eq 80
                exit
                action http-redirect "http://100.0.0.2/login.cgi?mac=$MAC$sap=$S
AP&ip=$IP&orig_url=$URL"
```

comments.author: sbarguil
comments.body: Do we want to make it at IP or application Level. It requires further discussions: usage and possible implementations.

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: @sbarguil, any update on this?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: As per the proposed plan in IETF#117

issues.title: ICMP matches: include identities for Types and Codes
issues.author: oscargdd
issues.body: Currently the members of an ICMP match are numbers. For the user defining the ACL, it is more intuitive and less prone to errors to write identities. However, given that ICMP types and codes are well documented by IANA, the suggestion is to create identities. A separate IANA-maintained module would be a good candidate to host the identities.

issues.title: Comments from Victor
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body:
Hi Med

I put below some editorial and readability improvements for the draft. Unfortunately, I did them with the version prior to Feb 1st. 
 
Abstract:
 
I would replace "This document discusses a set of extensions that fix many of the limitations of the ACL model as initially defined in RFC 8519." By "This document discusses a set of extensions that address some of the limitations of the ACL model as defined in RFC 8519." because it might not completely fix all the limitations. 
 
1. Introduction
 
Access control lists (ACLs)  Access Control Lists (ACLs)
 
If it is needed, for example,  If, for example, it is needed 
 
entering IP address  entering the IP address 
 
3.1.  Suboptimal Configuration: Lack of Support for Lists of Prefixes
 
IP prefix related data nodes  IP prefix-related data nodes 
 
DDoS attacks (e.g., RFC9132] when a set of sources are involved  DDoS attacks, e.g., [RFC9132], when a set of sources are involved
 
This sentence is not clear for me: 
 
“Such a configuration is suboptimal for both: - Network controllers that need to manipulate large files.” I think it is missing some information. Network controllers and… My guess is that it should be something like 
 
Such a configuration is suboptimal for both: network controllers and devices. Network controllers need to manipulate large files and they will need to pass all or a subset of the configuration to the underlying network devices. The devices will need to maintain the information locally and perform multiple configurations.
 
Confirguration  configuration
 
(Figure 2 depicts  Figure 2 depicts
 
3.2.  Manageability: Impossibility to Use Aliases or Defined Sets
 
Introduing  introducing
 
Each category is modelled 
 
Make uses  make use
 
ICMP sets: Uses  ICMP Used
 
to managed resources   to manage resources 
 
3.4. Partial or Lack of IPv4/IPv6 Fragment Handling
 
The sentence "does not support fragment handling capability for IPv6" I would changed it to "does not support fragment handling for IPv6" to improve readability
 
IPv4 by means of 'flags'  IPv4 through the use of 'flags'
 
allow a bitmask to be defined  allow the use of bitmasks.
 
Defining a new IPv4/IPv6 matching field called 'fragment' is thus required  As a result, a new IPv4/IPv6 matching field called 'fragment' is defined 
 
3.5.  Suboptimal TCP Flags Handling
 
The sentence "Defining this field to be defined as a flag bitmask together with a set of operations is meant to efficiently handle TCP flags filtering rules" I would changed it to "Defining this field as a flag bitmask with a set of operations can improve the efficiency of handling TCP flags filtering rules" 
 
3.6.  Rate-Limit Action
 
Such capability is not currently supported  This capability (as it was already described)
 
3.7.  Payload-based Filtering
                                                                                               
Some transport protocols use existing protocols  Some transport protocols rely on existing protocols
 
It is not clear to me why this section highlights the same gap in the two models. Someone can ask for a solution. 
 
3.8.  Reuse the ACLs Content Across Several Devices
 
following the hierarchy of the network topology  based on the network topology hierarchy
 
“then, that same ACL can be used (or referenced to) in several devices (including termination points) within the same network” I would change it for “then reused or referenced across multiple devices, including termination points within the same network”
 
4.5.  Rate-Limit Traffic
 
(#example_5) shows an ACL example to rate-limit incoming SYNs during a SYN flood attack.  I think it is a missing link to the figure

YANG file some typos

          leaf-list protocol {
            type union {
              type uint8;
              type string; //Check if we can reuse an IANA-maintained module
            }
            description
              "Value of the protocl set.";  protocol
          }
 
Regards,
 
Victor

issues.title: Implement all the recos in draft-boucadair-netmod-iana-registries
issues.author: boucadair

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body:
can be closed as it is already in the introduction 

The document also defines an IANA-maintained module for ICMP types. The design of the module adheres with the recommendations in [[I-D.boucadair-netmod-iana-registries](https://boucadair.github.io/enhanced-acl-netmod/draft-ietf-netmod-acl-extensions.html#I-D.boucadair-netmod-iana-registries)]. A template to generate the module is available at [Appendix A](https://boucadair.github.io/enhanced-acl-netmod/draft-ietf-netmod-acl-extensions.html#template). Readers should refer to the IANA website [REF_TBC] to retrieve the latest version of the module. The module is provided in [Appendix B](https://boucadair.github.io/enhanced-acl-netmod/draft-ietf-netmod-acl-extensions.html#iana-icmp) for the users convenience, but that appendix will be removed from the final RFC.

issues.title: Consider common actions
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: in addition to those in the draft. less common ones to be out of scope

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body:
- remark / assign a forwarding class **too close to QoS**
- log action: supported in Cisco, Juniper and Nokia
- update a variable/counter: a name of the counter/policy is provided
- raise an alarm **will require configuring where/proto to send the alarm**
- drop-extracted-traffic (Nokia specific) **out of scope**
- actions on inner part of the packet in case of encapsulation
- bind to a VRF/NAT/etc. **check if this similar to binding to an egress interface/vrf**
- set a priority for congestion case **may be tooooo close to QoS handling**
-

issues.title: In pyang, the match elements added appear one hierarchy level below.
issues.author: oscargdd
issues.body:
When compiling via pyang I noticed that the tructure in ipv6 had the match items defined in the document one level below. See:
```
     |        |  |  +--:(ipv6)
     |        |  |     +--rw ipv6 {match-on-ipv6}?
     |        |  |     |  +--rw dscp?                             inet:dscp
     |        |  |     |  +--rw ecn?                              uint8
     |        |  |     |  +--rw length?                           uint16
     |        |  |     |  +--rw ttl?                              uint8
     |        |  |     |  +--rw protocol?                         uint8
     |        |  |     |  +--rw (destination-network)?
     |        |  |     |  |  +--:(destination-ipv6-network)
     |        |  |     |  |     +--rw destination-ipv6-network?   inet:ipv6-prefix
     |        |  |     |  +--rw (source-network)?
     |        |  |     |  |  +--:(source-ipv6-network)
     |        |  |     |  |     +--rw source-ipv6-network?        inet:ipv6-prefix
     |        |  |     |  +--rw flow-label?                       inet:ipv6-flow-label
     |        |  |     +--rw acl-enh:ipv6-fragment
     |        |  |     |  +--rw acl-enh:operator?   operator
     |        |  |     |  +--rw acl-enh:type?       fragment-type
     |        |  |     +--rw acl-enh:source-ipv6-prefix-list?        ipv6-prefix-set-ref
     |        |  |     +--rw acl-enh:destination-ipv6-prefix-list?   ipv6-prefix-set-ref
     |        |  |     +--rw acl-enh:protocol-set?                   protocol-set-ref
```
Same happens with other augmentations...  is it a "bug" of pyang? Or it is that the augment needs something else?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body: @oscargdd, can you check https://github.com/boucadair/enhanced-acl-netmod/pull/46/files?

issues.title: WG last call comments from Mahesh
issues.author: oscargdd
issues.body:
- The Security Considerations section has both the read/write nodes and the read-only nodes as empty (or marked as TBC, which I imagine stands for To Be Completed). This needs to be filled out, or if no nodes are worth any security considerations, it should be stated so, and why.

- Isn’t the YANG model normative portion of the document? Isn’t what this document all about? Why is it then in the Appendix?

- Why is the Section titled "Initial Version of the The ICMPv4 Types IANA-Maintained Module”, when the model in question is "[iana-icmpv6-types@2020-09-25.yang](mailto:iana-icmpv6-types@2020-09-25.yang)”?

- ‘defined-sets’ and ‘aliases’ have been defined in a the separate model ‘ietf-acl-enh’. Are these sets and aliases defined to be used outside of ACL? If that is the case then having them outside the ‘ietf-access-control-list’ model makes sense. Otherwise, almost everything in the ‘ietf-acl-enh’ is an augmentation of the model defined in RFC 8519, as stated in the Introduction of the document

"The YANG module in this document is solely based on augmentations to the ACL YANG module defined in [RFC8519].”

If that is the case I see no reason why those containers should not be augmentations into the same model, as in

augment “/acl” {
  container defined-sets {
  ….
  }

  container aliases {
     …
  }
}
  

- I just pulled down the latest version (-03) of the draft, and ran into this error. 

$ pyang [ietf-acl-enh@2022-10-24.yang](mailto:ietf-acl-enh@2022-10-24.yang) 
[iana-icmpv6-types@2020-09-25.yang](mailto:iana-icmpv6-types@2020-09-25.yang):1: error: unexpected latest revision "2023-04-28" in [iana-icmpv6-types@2020-09-25.yang](mailto:iana-icmpv6-types@2020-09-25.yang), should be "2020-09-25”.

- Section 3.4. TCP Flags Handling. The document states that. 

"Clients that support both 'flags-bitmask' and 'flags' matching fields MUST NOT set these fields in the same request.”.

Can the model have a must statement to prevent this from being configured inadvertently?

Same for Section 3.5 Fragments Handling

- There should be clear direction to the RFC Editor on what should be done with revision dates. The same is true for other placeholder text. For example, what is the RFC Editor to do with text "RFC XXXX"?

- References in the YANG model should be expanded to include the title of the RFC.

- Examples are always good. Not only can they be used to validate the model, but users get to understand how it can be used. See other models such as BGP, TCP, BFD on how an example can be added.

- How is this a reference?
        reference
          "- Bill Simpson <mailto:Bill.Simpson&[um.cc.umich.edu](http://um.cc.umich.edu/)>

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body:
How is this a reference?
reference
"- Bill Simpson [mailto:Bill.Simpson&[um.cc.umich.edu](http://um.cc.umich.edu/)](mailto:Bill.Simpson&%5Bum.cc.umich.edu%5D(http://um.cc.umich.edu/))

We are echoing IANA registry, so we do not have control over that reference.

comments.author: oscargdd
comments.body:
References in the YANG model should be expanded to include the title of the RFC.

We are echoing IANA registry, so we do not have control over these references.

issues.title: Isn’t the YANG model normative portion of the document
issues.author: boucadair
issues.body: Isn’t the YANG model normative portion of the document? Isn’t what this document all about? Why is it then in the Appendix?

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
That is to comply with this part from 8407bis: 

> It is RECOMMENDED to include the URL from where to retrieve the recent version of the module. When a script is used, the Internet-Draft that defines an IANA-maintained module SHOULD include an appendix with the initial full version of the module. Including such an appendix in pre-RFC versions is meant to assess the correctness of the outcome of the supplied script. The authors MUST include a note to the RFC Editor requesting that the appendix be removed before publication as RFC and that RFC IIII is replaced with the RFC number that is assigned to the document. Initial versions of IANA-maintained modules that are published in RFCs may be misused despite the appropriate language to refer to the IANA registry to retrieve the up-to-date module. This is problematic for interoperability, e.g., when values are deprecated or are associated with a new meaning.

pulls.title: TCP Flags Clarification
pulls.author: sbarguil
pulls.body: tcp flags match is very difficult to understand,

comments.author: boucadair
comments.body:
The design in the draft is aligned with the practices, e.g., in https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc5575. 

I have a concern with the proposed changes as they cannot allow to enforce policies on the flags that are not currently assigned by IANA. This is problematic.

comments.author: sbarguil
sbarguil
comments.body: @sbarguil check descriptions and allign.

reviews.author: boucadair
reviews.body: Thanks @sbarguil for this updated version. Please find herein some comments.

comments.body: Not sure what retransmission is mentioned here. Please check the full flags at: https://www.iana.org/assignments/tcp-parameters/tcp-parameters.xhtml#tcp-header-flags
Idem as the previous comment
Such flag was deprecated by [RFC8311](https://www.iana.org/go/rfc8311)]

We need to indicate that this one is inferior to the full bitmask as checks only on known flags may let pass some packets while they carry "weird" flags (e.g.. SYN set but bit position 6 is also set.)

https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc9293.html#name-tcp-connection-failures: There are two thresholds R1 and R2 measuring the amount of retransmission that has occurred for the same segment. R1 and R2 might be measured in time units or as a count of retransmissions (with the current RTO and corresponding backoffs as a conversion factor, if needed).

pulls.title: Add units in the description for clarification
pulls.author: sbarguil

pulls.title: Fixing nits suggested by Mahesh
pulls.author: sbarguil
pulls.body:
COMMENT:

"Abstract", paragraph 2
>    RFC 8519 defines a YANG data model for Access Control Lists (ACLs).
>    This document discusses a set of extensions that fix many of the
>    limitations of the ACL model as initially defined in RFC 8519.
> 
>    The document also defines IANA-maintained modules for ICMP types and
>    IPv6 extension headers.

This document provided important extensions to the base ACL YANG model defined in RFC8519.

However, nowhere in the document does it mention that these extensions augment the base model, except in the model itself. Reading the abstract and the introduction, a reader would be left wondering whether this model is replacing RFC 8519 or augmenting it. Can that be made clear?

Section 2, paragraph 4
>    Defined set:  Refers to reusable description of one or multiple
>       information elements (e.g., IP address, IP prefix, port number, or
>       ICMP type).

Is it just a description? A better way to define it would be to say:

Elements in a defined set typically share a logical purpose or function, such as IP address, IP prefixes, port number, or ICMP type.

Similarly definition of 'payload-based filtering' could be added to define the term or referenced if defined somewhere else.

Section 3.5, paragraph 1
>    The augmented ACL structure (Figure 1) includes new leafs
>    'ipv4-fragment' and 'ipv6-fragment' to better handle fragments.

The document comments that RFC8519 does not do a good job of handling fragments and that this document addresses that issue. It would help to explain how the model defined in the document allows for better handling of fragments. For example, describe how the combination of operator and fragment type eases fragment handling.

Section 4, paragraph 1
>    This model imports types from [RFC6991], [RFC8519], and [RFC8294].

Thanks first of all to Per for providing YANG doctor review comments. I also tend to agree with him that as a practice reference to RFC 9293, 4443, 3032, 792, and IEEE 802.1Q, IEEE 802.1ah need to be added here, even if they are referenced or mentioned elsewhere.

"Appendix E.", paragraph 1
>    This section provides a few examples to illustrate the use of the
>    enhanced ACL module ("ietf-acl-enh").

Thank you for providing examples along with the module. The added feature in this module is payload-based filtering. An example configuration reflecting that, say for HTTP headers, would greatly enhance the understanding of this module.

No reference entries found for these items, which were mentioned in the text:
 [RFC3692].

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NIT
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

All comments below are about very minor potential issues that you may choose to
address in some way - or ignore - as you see fit. Some were flagged by
automated tools (via https://github.com/larseggert/ietf-reviewtool) so there
will likely be some false positives. There is no need to let me know what you
did with these suggestions.

Section 3.6, paragraph 2
>    A new feature, called 'match-on-payload', is defined in the document.
>    This can be used, for example, for QUIC [RFC9000] or for tunneling
>    protocols.  This feature requires configuring a data offset, a
>    length, and a binary pattern to macth data against using a specified
>    operator.

s/macth/match/

Section 6.3.1, paragraph 15
>    IANA is requested to updated the "Reference" in the "ICMP Type
>    Numbers" registry as follows:

s/updated/update/

Section 6.3.2, paragraph 15
>    IANA is requested to updated the "Reference" in the "ICMPv6 "type"
>    Numbers" registry as follows:

s/updated/update/

Section 6.3.3, paragraph 15
>    IANA is requested to updated the "Reference" in the "IPv6 Extension
>    Header Types" registry as follows:

s/updated/update/

Section 1.1, paragraph 10
> ixes, port number, or ICMP type. Similarly definition of 'payload-based filt
>                                  ^^^^^^^^^
A comma may be missing after the conjunctive/linking adverb "Similarly".

Section 4, paragraph 3
>  { base tcp-flag; description "Acknowledgment TCP flag bit."; reference "RFC
>                                ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
Do not mix variants of the same word ("acknowledgment" and "acknowledgement")

comments.body:
```suggestion
{{example_p}} This rule focuses entirely on the TCP payload, ignoring other parts of the TCP segment (such as the TCP header or options). By using an offset at the payload, it allows targeting a specific portion of the payload that starts 20 bytes after the beginning of the data (skipping the first 20 bytes).
This approach might be useful for detecting specific patterns, signatures, or protocols encapsulated within the payload, such as when the inner source IP address is 2001:db8::1.
```
